case_name: Indore Municipality v. Trustees of a charitable trust

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 141 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 378 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 141 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 378 of 1961.

facts.text: The respondents as trustees of a charitable trust are the owners of certain houses situate in Indore City.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents as trustees of a charitable trust are the owners of certain houses situate in Indore City.

facts.text: Prior to January 26, 1954 the Indore Municipality was governed by the Indore City Municipal Act, 4 of 1909.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to January 26, 1954 the Indore Municipality was governed by the Indore City Municipal Act, 4 of 1909.

facts.text: By virtue of the power conferred on it by that Act the Municipality used to levy and collect house tax at the rate of 7% of the gross annual letting value of these houses and the trustees duly paid such tax.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the power conferred on it by that Act the Municipality used to levy and collect house tax at the rate of 7 of the gross annual letting value of these houses and the trustees duly paid such tax.

facts.text: The Madhya Bharat Municipalities Act, 1954 came into force on January 26, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: After the formation of the State of Madhya Bharat, the legislature of that State passed the Madhya Bharat Municipalities Act, 1954 which came into force on January 26, 1954.

facts.text: The 1954 Act repealed amongst other Acts the Indore City Municipal Act, 1909.

anchor.surface_text: The 1954 Act repealed amongst other Acts the Indore City Municipal Act, 1909.

facts.text: The Indore Municipality purported to levy the house tax on the basis of the gross annual letting value at the rate of 7% of such value for the financial years 1953-54 and 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The Indore Municipality however purported to levy the house tax on the basis of the gross annual letting value at the rate of 7 of such value for the financial years 1953-54 and 1954-55.

facts.text: This was objected to by the respondents on the ground that under the 1954 Act the tax could be assessed on the basis of gross annual letting value less 10% statutory allowance in lieu of costs of repairs or on any other account whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: This was objected to by the respondents on the ground that under the 1954 Act the tax could be assessed on the basis of gross annual letting value less 10 statutory allowance in. lieu of costs of repairs or on any other account whatsoever.

facts.text: The difference came to Rs. 1,461, and of this the trustees claimed refund on the ground that the Municipality had collected the excess from them under pain of distress.

anchor.surface_text: The difference came to Rs. 1,461, and of this the trustees claimed refund on the ground that the Municipality had collected the excess from them under pain of distress.

facts.text: The Municipality having refused to refund the excess the respondents filed the suit to recover it on the ground that the excess amount was illegally recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality having refused to refund the excess the respondents filed the suit to recover it on the ground that the excess amount was illegally recovered.

facts.text: The Trial Court decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court decreed the suit and the appeals filed by the Corporation in the District Court and the High Court were dismissed.

facts.text: The appeals filed by the Corporation in the District Court and the High Court were dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court decreed the suit and the appeals filed by the Corporation in the District Court and the High Court were dismissed.

facts.text: Under the rules made under the repealed Indore City Municipal Act, 1909 the Municipality had imposed the tax on houses at the rate of 7% of their gross annual letting value.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed by Counsel that under the rules made under the repealed Indore City Municipal Act, 1909 the Municipality had imposed the tax on houses at the rate of 7 of their gross annual letting value, that an assessment list on that basis was prepared for the year 1952-53

facts.text: An assessment list on that basis was prepared for the year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: that an assessment list on that basis was prepared for the year 1952-53 and that the Municipality has been levying tax at the said rate on the basis of the said assessment list for the two subsequent years.

facts.text: The Municipality has been levying tax at the said rate on the basis of the said assessment list for the two subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Municipality has been levying tax at the said rate on the basis of the said assessment list for the two subsequent years.

facts.text: Counsel for the appellant Corporation argued that the Corporation was entitled to levy the house tax at the rate of 7% of the gross annual letting value and that it was not bound to deduct the 10% allowance provided by sec. 73(2) from such gross annual letting value.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant Corporation argued that the Corporation was entitled to levy the house tax at the rate of 7 of the gross annual letting value and that it was not bound to deduct the 10 allowance provided by sec. 73 2  from such gross annual letting value.

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore was right in decreeing the suit and to order refund of the said excess amount against the appellant Corporation. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Sec. 21 of the Indore City Municipal Act authorised the Municipal Council to impose tax on houses, buildings or lands within the municipal limits at a rate not exceeding 12-1/2% of the gross annual letting value.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 21 of the Indore City Municipal Act authorised the Municipal Council to impose tax on houses, buildings or lands within the municipal limits at a rate number exceeding 12-1/2 of the gross annual letting value.

facts.text: The Indore Municipal Act being no longer in force as from January 26, 1954, obviously no tax could be levied or imposed thereunder after that date.

anchor.surface_text: The Indore Municipal Act being no longer in force as from January 26, 1954, obviously no tax could be levied or imposed thereunder after that date.

facts.text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act.

facts.text: The appellant Corporation was not entitled to demand the tax assessed on the gross annual letting value.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the appellant-Corporation was not entitled to demand the tax assessed on the gross annual letting value.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court
Indore City Municipal Act, 4 of 1909.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 2 of the 1954 Act which contains both a repealing and saving provisions repealed the several Acts set out therein. Clause (a) however provides that such repeal shall number affect the validity or invalidity of anything already done under any of the said enactments. Clause (c) of sec. 2 provides that all rules, orders, byelaws, numberifications and numberices, taxes and rates, made, passed, framed, issued or imposed or deemed to have been made, passed, framed, issued or imposed, shall so far as they are number inconsistent with this Act, be deemed to have been made, passed, framed, issued or imposed, as the case may be, under this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Saves rules, taxes, rates under repealed Acts only if not inconsistent with the new Act; deeming provision qualified by consistency requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 73 provides that when a tax on buildings or lands or both is imposed, the Chief Executive Officer shall cause an assessment list of all buildings or lands in the municipality to be prepared containing the particulars therein set out. Amongst such particulars are the valuation based on capital or annual letting value as the case may be on which the property is assessed. Sub-sec. 2 provides that in assessing the tax on buildings or lands, where the valuation determined under clause (d) of sub-section (1) is the annual letting value, a sum equal to 10 of such valuation shall be deducted therefrom in lieu of allowance for costs of repairs or on any account whatsoever.

concepts.interpretation: Requires assessment of house tax on annual letting value less 10% deduction for repairs etc.; old gross value basis inconsistent with this provision.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: x assessed on the basis of such valuation or annual letting value. Under ss. 75 and 76 when the assessment list is prepared in accordance with the pro

concepts.unlisted_description: Assessment list and net annual letting value basis for tax (10% deduction)

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 75 provides for the publication of the assessment list and the. right of the owner or occupier of properties included in the list to take inspection thereof and to make extracts therefrom.

concepts.interpretation: Requires publication of assessment list and right to inspect and object.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: on 6 lays down that subject to such alterations as may be made therein under sec. 77 and to the result of any appeal or revision made under sec. 190 i

concepts.unlisted_description: Publication and inspection of assessment list

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 76 provides for a public notice of time fixed for lodging objections to such assessment list and the hearing of such objections. Sub-sec. 4 of sec. 76 provides for the authentication of the list. Sub-section 6 lays down that subject to such alterations as may be made therein under sec. 77 and to the result of any appeal or revision made under sec. 190 in the case of City Municipality and. under sec. 90 in the case of other municipalities, the entries in the assessment list so authenticated shall be accepted as conclusive evidence for the purposes of all municipal taxes of the valuation or annual letting value of buildings. and lands to which such entries respectively refer and for the purposes of the tax for which such assessment list has been prepared of the amount of tax leviable on such buildings or lands in any official year in which such list is in force.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for objections, authentication, and conclusive evidence effect of assessment list only after following procedure; applies even to adopted lists.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ual letting value or the tax assessed thereon for at least 4 years even though the valuation or the annual letting value thereof may have decreased fo

concepts.unlisted_description: Objections, authentication, and conclusive evidence for assessment lists

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 79 (1) provides that it would number be necessary for a Municipality to prepare a new assessment list for every year. It further provides that subject to the condition that such assessment list shall be completely revised number less than once in every 4 years the Municipality may adopt the valuation and assessment contained in the list for any year with such alterations as may be necessary for the year immediately following. But sub-section 2 lays down that the provisions of s. 75 and s. 76 shall be applicable every year as if a new assessment list has been completed at the commencement of the official year.

concepts.interpretation: Permits adoption of prior assessment lists not more than once every 4 years but requires annual application of ss.75-76 procedure as if new list; does not override Sec.73(2) deduction.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ual letting value or the tax assessed thereon for at least 4 years even though the valuation or the annual letting value thereof may have decreased fo

concepts.unlisted_description: Adoption of prior assessment lists with annual procedure compliance

anchor.surface_text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act. The saving and the deeming provisions in s. 2 c can only apply if the tax is assessed in the manner consistent with the provisions of s. 73, that is, if it is assessed-on the net and number the gross annual letting value after deducting 10 statutory allowance in lieu of the costs of repairs or any other account whatsoever. If the construction of sec. 2 c as suggested by Counsel were to.be accepted it would render sec. 73 (2) nugatory

concepts.interpretation: Saving clause under Sec.2(c) must be construed harmoniously with Sec.73(2); old tax basis inconsistent and not saved if it renders new provision nugatory.

issues.text: Whether the rules and tax levy at 7% of gross annual letting value under the repealed Indore City Municipal Act are saved by Section 2(c) of the 1954 Act so as to permit levy without deducting 10% under Section 73(2)

anchor.surface_text: firstly, that the appellant Corporation companyld do so because the rules made under the Indore Act are saved by sec. 2 c  and therefore the rate of 7 of the gross annual letting value at which the tax was levied also has been saved

issues.text: Whether adoption of the 1952-53 assessment list under Section 79(1) for 1953-54 and 1954-55 years renders it conclusive evidence under Section 76(6) of annual letting value and tax amount on gross basis without following Sections 75 and 76 procedure and without Section 73(2) deduction

anchor.surface_text: secondly, that under sec. 79 1  of the 1954 Act the Corporation need number prepare a fresh assessment list every year, that it has to prepare a fresh assessment list only once in every 4 years, that the Corporation therefore can and in fact has adopted the said list for the two years in question and that being so, the list so adopted was. in force during the years in question and has to be accepted under s. 76 6  as conclusive evidence of the annual letting value as also for the amount of tax leviable on the buildings or lands or both.

The saving and the deeming provisions in s. 2 c can only apply if the tax is assessed in the manner consistent with the provisions of s. 73

arguments.claim: Accepting petitioner's construction of s.2(c) would render s.73(2) nugatory

anchor.surface_text: If the construction of sec. 2 c as suggested by Counsel were to.be accepted it would render sec. 73 2 nugatory, for, the Municipal Corporation in that case can go on imposing the tax on the basis of the gross annual letting value for ever despite the express provision for levying tax on the basis of net annual letting value

arguments.claim: Even adopted assessment list under s.79 must follow ss.75-76 procedure annually and comply with s.73(2); becomes conclusive only after authentication post-objections

anchor.surface_text: But sub-sec. 2 of sec. 79 provides expressly that when such a previous list is adopted for a particular official year it can be done subject to the provisions of sections 75 and 76... The list so adopted has therefore to be published, has to invite objections and has to be authenticated in the manner prescribed by sec. 76 6 after disposing of the objections if any and it is then only that it becomes conclusive evidence

arguments.claim: Appellant Corporation not entitled to demand tax on gross annual letting value

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the appellant-Corporation was not entitled to demand the tax assessed on the gross annual letting value.

holdings.text: The Indore Municipal Act being no longer in force as from January 26, 1954, obviously no tax could be levied or imposed thereunder after that date.

anchor.surface_text: The Indore Municipal Act being no longer in force as from January 26, 1954, obviously no tax could be levied or imposed thereunder after that date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of repeal effect; post-repeal, old Act cannot authorize levy.

holdings.text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act. The saving and the deeming provisions in s. 2(c) can only apply if the tax is assessed in the manner consistent with the provisions of s. 73, that is, on the net annual letting value after deducting 10% statutory allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act. The saving and the deeming provisions in s. 2 c can only apply if the tax is assessed in the manner consistent with the provisions of s. 73, that is, if it is assessed-on the net and number the gross annual letting value after deducting 10 statutory allowance in lieu of the costs of repairs or any other account whatsoever.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: s.2(c) saving limited by consistency with s.73(2); alternative would render s.73(2) nugatory.

holdings.text: When a previous assessment list is adopted under sec. 79(1) for a subsequent year, the provisions of ss. 75 and 76 shall be applicable every year as if a new assessment list has been completed; the list so adopted has to be published, objections invited, and authenticated under s.76(6) to become conclusive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: But sub-sec. 2 of sec. 79 provides expressly that when such a previous list is adopted for a particular official year it can be done subject to the provisions of sections 75 and 76... The list so adopted has therefore to be published, has to invite objections and has to be authenticated in the manner prescribed by sec. 76 6 after disposing of the objections if any and it is then only that it becomes conclusive evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.79(2): annual procedure mandatory even for adopted lists to protect objection rights and ensure compliance with s.73.

holdings.text: The word 'if' appearing in sub-sec. 2 of sec. 79 is obviously a mistake and must be read as 'as if' because the word if standing by itself makes no sense at all.

anchor.surface_text: The word, if appearing in sub-sec. 2 of sec. 79 is obviously a mistake and must be read as as if because the word if standing by itself makes numbersense at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual interpretation to make statutory language sensible.

holdings.text: The appellant-Corporation was not entitled to demand the tax assessed on the gross annual letting value.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the appellant-Corporation was not entitled to demand the tax assessed on the gross annual letting value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts: inconsistent levy not permitted, refund due.

holdings.text: The High Court therefore was right in decreeing the suit and to order refund of the said excess amount against the appellant Corporation. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore was right in decreeing the suit and to order refund of the said excess amount against the appellant Corporation. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The tax levied under the old Act and the rules framed thereunder on the basis of the gross annual letting value is obviously inconsistent with the provisions of s. 73 of the Act. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
